S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Success rates of different methods on Meta-world environments with K=3𝐾3K=3. Each data point comes from 20 random seeds.
references: 1 shows success rates of different methods in ML10 and ML45 suites with sub-skill number K=3𝐾3K=3. We perform 1-shot and 3-shot experiments respectively to show the progressive few-shot performance of different methods. DMIL achieves the best results in ML10 testing suite and ML45 training and testing suites. This shows the superiority of our method for transferring across a large scale of manipulation tasks. OptionGAIL achieves high success rates in both ML10 and ML45 training suites. These results come from their hierarchical structures that have adequate capacity to fit potential multi-modal behaviors in multi-task demonstrations. MIL achieves comparable results for all meta-testing tasks but is worse than DMIL. This shows the necessity of meta-learning processes. Compared to them, PEMIRL and MLSH are mediocre among all suites. This comes from that the reward functions across different tasks are difficult to transfer with few shot demonstrations, and the relearned high-level network of MLSH damages previously learned knowledge. We also illustrate t-sne results of these methods in 4(a) to further analyze them in appendix D.2.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2: Cumulative rewards of different methods on four unseen tasks in Kitchen environment with K=4𝐾4K=4. Boldface indicates excluded objects during training.
references: 2 shows the rewards of different methods on four unseen tasks in the Kitchen environment. FIST-no-FT refers to a variant of FIST that does not use future state conditioning, which makes the comparison fairer. DMIL achieves higher rewards on two out of four tasks and comparable results on the other two tasks, which exhibits the effectiveness of the bi-level meta-training procedure. The poor performance of DMIL on the first task may come from the choice of skill number K𝐾K or from low-quality demonstrations. We perform ablation studies on K𝐾K in the next section.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3: Success rates of different sub-skill number in Meta-world environments.
references: Effect of different skill number K𝐾K: 3 shows the effect of different sub-skill number K𝐾K in Meta-world experiments. We can see that a larger K𝐾K can lead to higher success rates on meta-training tasks, but a smaller K𝐾K can lead to better results on meta-testing tasks. This tells us that an excessive number of sub-skills may result in over-fitting on training data, and a smaller K𝐾K can play the role of regularization. In Kitchen experiments, we can see similar phenomenons in 5. It is worth noting in both environments, we did not encounter collapse problems, i.e., every sub-skill gets well-trained even when K=8𝐾8K=8 in kitchen environment or K=10𝐾10K=10 in Meta-world environments. This may come from that, in the meta-training stage, adding more sub-skills can help the whole structure get lower loss, thus DMIL will use all of them for training. However, in our supplementary videos, we can see sub-skills trained with a large K𝐾K (for instance, K=10𝐾10K=10 in Meta-world environments) are not as semantic as sub-skills trained by a small K𝐾K (for instance, K=3𝐾3K=3 in Meta-world environments) during the execution of a task.

A4.T4.caption: Table 4: Success rates of DMIL-High, DMIL-Low, DMIL and OptionGAIL on Meta-world environments with K=3𝐾3K=3. Each data point comes from the success rate of 20 tests.
references: 4 shows the results of this ablation study. DMIL-High achieves close results with OptionGAIL in all meta-training suites and better results in all meta-testing suites, but worse than DMIL in all cases. This shows that meta-learning the high-level network can help the hierarchical structure adapt to new tasks, but only transferring the high-level network is not enough for accomplish all kinds of new tasks. DMIL-Low achieves poor results in all suites except in ML10 meta-training suites. This shows that transferring the high-level network is necessary when training on a large scale of tasks or testing in new tasks.

A4.T5.caption: Table 5: Ablations of sub-skill number K𝐾K in Kitchen environments.
A4.T5.table:
Task (Unseen) K=2 K=4 K=8
Microwave, Kettle, Top Burner, Light Switch 1.9±plus-or-minus\pm0.43 1.5±plus-or-minus\pm0.48 1.7±plus-or-minus\pm0.22
Microwave, Bottom Burner, Light Switch, Slide Cabinet 2.15±plus-or-minus\pm0.19 2.35±plus-or-minus\pm0.39 2.0±plus-or-minus\pm0.37
Microwave, Kettle, Hinge Cabinet, Slide Cabinet 2.45±plus-or-minus\pm0.25 3.15±plus-or-minus\pm0.22 1.85±plus-or-minus\pm0.23
Microwave, Kettle, Hinge Cabinet, Slide Cabinet 2.01±plus-or-minus\pm0.24 2.95±plus-or-minus\pm0.44 2.44±plus-or-minus\pm0.47
references: Effect of different skill number K𝐾K: 3 shows the effect of different sub-skill number K𝐾K in Meta-world experiments. We can see that a larger K𝐾K can lead to higher success rates on meta-training tasks, but a smaller K𝐾K can lead to better results on meta-testing tasks. This tells us that an excessive number of sub-skills may result in over-fitting on training data, and a smaller K𝐾K can play the role of regularization. In Kitchen experiments, we can see similar phenomenons in 5. It is worth noting in both environments, we did not encounter collapse problems, i.e., every sub-skill gets well-trained even when K=8𝐾8K=8 in kitchen environment or K=10𝐾10K=10 in Meta-world environments. This may come from that, in the meta-training stage, adding more sub-skills can help the whole structure get lower loss, thus DMIL will use all of them for training. However, in our supplementary videos, we can see sub-skills trained with a large K𝐾K (for instance, K=10𝐾10K=10 in Meta-world environments) are not as semantic as sub-skills trained by a small K𝐾K (for instance, K=3𝐾3K=3 in Meta-world environments) during the execution of a task.

We perform ablation studies of sub-skill number K𝐾K on the Kitchen environments and choose K=2,4,8𝐾248K=2,4,8 respectively. 5 shows the results. We can see that a smaller number of sub-skills can achieve better results on such four unseen results that a large number of sub-skills. This may indicate that the sub-skill number K𝐾K can work as a ’bottleneck’ like the middle layer in an auto-encoder.

It controls the balance between under-fitting and over-fitting. We perform ablation studies of fine-tune steps in Meta-world benchmarks with K=5𝐾5K=5 and lr=1e-2 in 6. Results are as follows:

references: Although this operation seems discrete, in practice we can use the operations in modern deep learning framework such as PyTorch Paszke et al. (2019) to make it differentiable. We add this loss function to the ℒh​(θh,τi​1)subscriptℒℎsubscript𝜃ℎsubscript𝜏𝑖1\mathcal{L}_{h}(\theta_{h},\tau_{i1}) and ∇θhℒ​(λh,τi​3)subscript∇subscript𝜃ℎℒsubscript𝜆ℎsubscript𝜏𝑖3\nabla_{\theta_{h}}\mathcal{L}(\lambda_{h},\tau_{i3}) with a coefficient λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1. We also perform ablation studies of ℒa​u​xsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑢𝑥\mathcal{L}_{aux} and results are in 7.

We perform ablation studies of the effect of continuity regularization as following 7. DMIL_nc means no continuity regularization. We can see that the continuity constraint would damage meta-training performance slightly, but increase the meta-testing performance greatly.

A4.T8.caption: Table 8: Ablation about hard/soft EM choices with K=5𝐾5K=5 in the Meta-world environments.
A4.T8.table:
ML10 ML45
Meta-training Meta-testing Meta-training Meta-testing
variants 1-shot 3-shot 1-shot 3-shot 1-shot 3-shot 1-shot 3-shot
DMIL 0.795 0.94 0.52 0.57 0.713333 0.92 0.21 0.48
DMIL_soft 0.37 0.65 0.33 0.46 0.235556 0.43 0.1 0.32
Gap 0.425 0.29 0.19 0.11 0.477778 0.49 0.11 0.16
references: In DMIL, we use hard EM algorithm to train the high-level network. One may think about to use soft cross entropy loss to train the high-level network to get better results. We perform this ablation study in the following 8. We can see that a soft cross entropy training won’t help increase the whole success rates. This may comes from that, usually we use soft cross entropy (such as label smoothing) to prevent over-fitting. However, in our situation, this may cause under-fitting, since training on such a large scale of diverse manipulation tasks is already very difficult. Future works can seek more comparisons about this choice.

A5.T9.caption: Table 9: DMIL hyper-parameters.
A5.T9.table:
Parameter Value
α𝛼\alpha 5e-4
β𝛽\beta 1e-4
fine-tune iterations 3
batch size (in trajectory) 16
λ𝜆\lambda 0.1
references: DMIL: The high-level network and each sub-skill is modeled with a 4-layer fully-connected neuron network, with 512 ReLU units in each layer. We use Adam as the meta-optimizer. DMIL-High and DMIL-Low use the same architecture with DMIL. Hyper-parameter settings are available in table 9.

A5.T10.caption: Table 10: MIL hyper-parameters.
A5.T10.table:
Parameter Value
nh​e​a​dsubscript𝑛ℎ𝑒𝑎𝑑n_{head} 8
nl​a​y​e​rsubscript𝑛𝑙𝑎𝑦𝑒𝑟n_{layer} 3
dm​o​d​e​lsubscript𝑑𝑚𝑜𝑑𝑒𝑙d_{model} 512

batch size (in state-action pair) 512
references: MIL: We use a transformer Vaswani et al. (2017) as the policy to perform MAML. The input of the encoder is the whole one-shot demonstration or 3-shot demonstrations with concatenated state and action. The input of the decoder is current state. The output is the predicted action. Hyper-parameter settings are available in 10.

A5.T11.caption: Table 11: MLSH hyper-parameters.
A5.T11.table:
Parameter Value
high-level learning rate 1e-3
sub-skill learning rate 1e-4
PPO clip threshold 0.02
high-level warmup step 500
joint update step 1000
batch size (in state-action pair) 900
references: MLSH: We use the same settings of network with DMIL here. The macro step of high-level network is 3. Since our problem is not a reinforcement learning process, we use the behavior cloning variant of MLSH. The pseudo reward is defined by the negative mean square loss of the predicted action and the ground truth, and we perform pseudo reinforcement learning process with off-policy demonstration data. We use PPO as our reinforcement learning algorithm. Note in this way we ignore the importance sampling weights that required by replacing the sampling process in the environments with the demonstrations in the replay buffer, which has been shown to be effective in practice in Kostrikov et al. (2018); Ghasemipour et al. (2019). Hyper-parameter settings are available in 11.

A5.T12.caption: Table 12: PEMIRL hyper-parameters.
A5.T12.table:
Parameter Value
learning rate of all models 1e-4
PPO clip threshold 0.02
coefficient (γ𝛾\gamma) of hϕsubscriptℎitalic-ϕh_{\phi} 1
β𝛽\beta 0.1
batch size (in trajectory) 16
references: PEMIRL: We use the same setting of the high-level network as the policy πωsubscript𝜋𝜔\pi_{\omega} and the inference model qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi} in PEMIRL. We use PPO as our reinforcement learning algorithm. We use a 3-layer fully-connected neuron network as the context-dependent disentangled reward estimator rθ​(s,m)subscript𝑟𝜃𝑠𝑚r_{\theta}(s,m) and the context-dependent potential function hϕ​(s,m)subscriptℎitalic-ϕ𝑠𝑚h_{\phi}(s,m). Here we also use the behavior cloning variant of PEMIRL to only train models on the off-policy data. Hyper-parameter settings are available in 12.
